abstract.p: The influence of pine fiber treatments on the color and chemical changes of polyvinyl chloride-based wood plastic composites exposed to outside and xenon-arc accelerated weathering was investigated. The wood plastic composites were produced from pine fiber (untreated control, acetone extracted, and holocellulose (delignified)) and polyvinyl chloride. Different analytical tools (colorimetry, microscopy, infrared spectroscopy, and gel permeation chromatography) were employed for weathered wood plastic composites characterization. The study showed that longer exposure time in both outside and accelerated weathering regimes caused an increase in color change and lightness, cracking, higher oxidation but decrease in wood (lignin) content of the weathered wood plastic composites’ surface for all the wood fiber types. The polyvinyl chloride molecular weight decreased with increase in exposure time of the composites. From this study, delignified wood fiber-based wood plastic composites had less color (lightness) change and reduced surface cracking with lowest weathered surface oxidation. Furthermore, relationships between accelerated and outside weathered wood plastic composite surfaces were observed.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Industrial and exterior applications of wood plastic composites (WPCs) are numerous while the increasing manufacturers’ acclaimed benefits over solid wood lumber appear to be a sign of future market growth. Interestingly, polyvinyl chloride (PVC) accounts for about 10–13% of WPC market in the year 2004, thereby ranking it as the second largest thermoplastics for WPC production.1 In addition, PVC supply is anticipated to reach a volume of 40 million tons by the year 2016.2 This projection is reasonable because of its low production cost, good processability, easy modification, and excellent chemical and fire resistance. Therefore, the excellent resistance properties earn PVC and its composites the popularity as an outdoor applications material. However, the problem of photodegradation of outdoor exposure of PVC-based WPC by ultraviolet (UV) radiation from sunlight is expected.3,4 Outdoor application of PVC-based WPC usually results in a severe loss of its aesthetic appearance and mechanical properties.3 Matuana et al.3 explained that the formation of polyene linkages due to dehydrochlorination is responsible for the change in the color of PVC. In addition, lignin degradation is also suggested to contribute to it.4 A previous study showed that the more the lignin degraded, the higher the oxidation, consequently, the higher the total color change and surface lightness.4 Lignin in wood strongly absorbs UV light, which eventually leads to radical-induced depolymerization of both lignin and cellulose at wood surfaces.5,6 However, cellulose is comparatively UV stable.7 Therefore, the use of delignified wood could enhance color stability and strength. Delignified wood fiber (holocellulose) has been found to enhance color stability of high-density polyethylene (HDPE)-based WPC.4 Unfortunately, the contribution of delignified wood fiber on color change of weathered PVC-based WPC has not been established. Note that color stability could come at the expense of wood properties due to the potential lack of compatibility between the wood fiber (pine, extracted, and delignified wood) and the polymer matrix. Therefore, measurement of the flexural properties and dimensional stability of the composites produced from modified wood is critical in insuring that the WPC will meet specifications.

During weathering of PVC, it is expected that its molecular weight (MW) to change as a result of the chain scission and cross-linking reactions, which occur due to the elimination of hydrogen chloride.3,8,9 These reactions have a great effect on polymer performance because the physical and mechanical properties of polymer are extremely sensitive to MW and molecular structure.10 Chain scission leads to shorter polymer chains which could cause lower mechanical properties. Matuana and Kamdem11 reported that the elongation at break of PVC-based WPC decreased upon weathering (embrittlement).

This study is aimed at investigating the influence of solvent extraction and delignification of wood fibers on the dimensional stability and mechanical properties of unweathered composites, the chemical and color changes of weathered PVC-based WPC. The MW of PVC was investigated to establish the effects of wood modification on the interactions between polymer matrix and wood fibers during weathering. It also aimed at finding the relationship that exist in the property change between outside and xenon-arc weathering.

sec.title: Materials and methods
sec.p: Pine wood fiber (60 mesh, American Wood Fibers, Schofield, WI) was solvent extracted in accordance with a modified Technical Association of Pulp and Paper Industry method (T204 om-88)12 using acetone (98%). Additionally, holocellulose (delignified) fiber preparation followed Wise et al.’s13 approach. A detailed description of fiber preparation is contained in Fabiyi et al.14 Note that only approximately 3.2% extractives (based on initial weight of wood) were removed by the acetone extraction technique. The adopted holocellulose preparation method produced about 67% holocellulose based on original wood with a lignin content <1.5%. The modified fibers (acetone extracted wood and holocellulose) were dried to below 0.5% moisture content prior to compounding.

A commercial rigid PVC compound (40%, LP, Geon E4000 Natural 0000) and the three types of wood fibers (60%) already prepared were used for WPC production. Materials were compounded (3–5 kg batch size) and extruded on a 35 mm counter-rotating conical twin-screw extruder (Cincinnati Milacron) to a profiled dimension of 9.5 × 38 mm2. The barrel and die temperatures were between 149°C and 193°C, respectively.
The extruded profiles were cooled by a showering system and then knife milled to a thickness of 5.0 mm for the weathering tests because many commercial WPC products are surface finished.

sec.title: Fiber characterization
sec.p: The thermal stability of the pine fiber (6–8 mg) was determined by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) using a Rheometrics STA 650 instrument (50–500°C at 10°C/min in a nitrogen atmosphere).

sec.title: Mechanical and water sorption properties of WPC produced from modified wood fiber
sec.p: Three-point flexural tests (modulus of rupture (MOR), modulus of elasticity (MOE)) were performed in accordance with ASTM Standard D 790-02.15 Seven replicates were performed for each WPC type (20 × 5.73 × 115 mm3) on an Instron 5500R-1137 universal test machine equipped with a 454 kg load cell. Data were collected and processed using Bluehill v2 software (Instron).

Water absorption (WA) and thickness swell (TS) tests were conducted following a modified ASTM D 570-98 procedure.16 Five replicate specimens (5 × 20 × 50 mm3) from each WPC were immersed in water at 23°C for 49 days and periodically weighed. Weight gain and TS were measured for determination of WA and TS, respectively.

sec.title: Accelerated and natural weathering of WPC
sec.p: PVC-based WPC wood specimens (5 × 38 × 101 mm3) were subjected to accelerated weathering test, which was conducted in a xenon-arc weatherometer (Xe-3, Q-Sun). The average irradiance was 0.70 W/m2 at 340 nm wavelength with a chamber temperature of 70°C and water spray in accordance with ASTM D 6662,17 which is a very severe weathering condition. The natural weathering test was conducted by exposing the WPC specimens (5 × 38 × 610 mm3) outside in Moscow, ID, USA on a south-facing wall at an angle of 45° in accordance with ASTM D 1435.18 The sample condition was assessed from 0 to 1200 h and 0 to 120 days of exposure in xenon-arc and outside weathering regimes, respectively.

sec.title: Characterization of weathered WPC
sec.p: Weathered WPC specimens were assessed by microscopy for surface morphology, color measurement by colorimetry, chemical change by an attenuated total reflectance–Fourier transform infrared (ATR–FT-IR) spectroscopy and MW distribution by gel permeation chromatography (GPC).14

sec.title: Surface appearance
sec.p: Scanning electron micrographs (SEM) of PVC-based WPC samples were obtained on a LEO Gemini field emission SEM instrument. Sections of unweathered, 400 and 1200 h xenon-arc weathered WPCs were cut into approximately 8 × 8 mm2 pieces and were analyzed directly (without coating) at 1 kV using a magnification of 70×.19

Changes in the color of weathered WPC surface were monitored following ASTM D 2244.20 A StellarNet EPP2000 UV-Vis spectrometer (190–850 nm) using a krypton light source (SL1, StellarNet) and a diffuse reflection fiber optic probe was used. Relative lightness (ΔLrel) and total color change (ΔEab) were calculated using the following equations (1) and (2) (1)ΔLrel=Lfinal*-Linitial*L*initial×100 (2)ΔEab=ΔL2+Δa2+Δb2 where ΔL, Δa, and Δb represent the differences between the initial and final values of L*, a*, and b*, respectively. An increase in L indicates increase in lightness. Relative lightness is employed because the color of the composites differs as a result of the differences in color of the modified wood used.

sec.title: Chemical characterization
sec.p: The WPC surface was chemically characterized by ATR–FT-IR spectroscopy (ThermoNicolet Avatar 370 FT-IR spectrometer with a ZnSe ATR cell (SmartPerformer)). Detailed descriptions of the data collection and computation techniques have been documented.4 A quantitative analysis estimating the molar concentration (c, mol/L) of each carbonyl group using Beer–Lambert equation was adopted from the protocol of Fabiyi et al.19 and Fabiyi and McDonald.4

In addition to the functional groups characterization, the effect of weathering on the MW of PVC was determined GPC on elution with tetrahydrofuran (THF). Prior to GPC analysis, the surface of unweathered and weathered WPC was scrapped and about 500 mg of material finely ground (60 mesh = 0.25 mm), vacuum dried then weighed, and THF (50 mL) was added. The contents were then heated with a microwave oven (Sanyo, 600 W) for 1 min to enable PVC solubilization while at the same time minimizing oxidation. The solubilized PVC was filtered and the extract evaporated to dryness under a stream of nitrogen and yield recorded. The extracts were dissolved in THF (3–5 mg/mL), filtered through 0.45 µm filter (PTFE) and analyzed by GPC analysis with refractive index (Waters model 2414), UV–vis (Waters model 2489), right and low-angle laser light scattering and differential viscometer detection (Viscotek Model 270). Separation was performed using two columns in series (Jordi Gel DVB mixed bed and 500 Å columns, 300 × 7.8 mm2) at 40°C on elution with THF (0.5 mL/min). Data were collected and analyzed using OmnicSEC v4.1 software (Viscotek) to calculate weight-average MW (Mw) and number-average MW (Mn). All the data were statistically analyzed using SPSS v16 software.

Mechanism of color and chemical changes

sec.title: Prediction of outside weathered WPC properties from xenon-arc weathering
sec.p: In establishing the relationships that exist between outside and xenon-arc weathering, two steps were taken. The first step taken was to predict color and some chemical changes of both outside and xenon-arc weathering based on the originally assessed outside exposure time of 0, 10, 30, 60, 90, and 120 days from the models that were developed (using equation (27)) using SPSS version 16.0. However, the exposure time (day) was converted to hours. The second step was to predict the color change, vinyl, and carbonyl concentrations of outside weathered from the originally assessed outside exposure time (h) and corresponding property of the theoretical data of xenon-arc weathered PVC-based WPC.

sec.title: Thermal stability of modified fiber
sec.p:
The TGA thermograms of the modified pine wood fibers are shown in Figure 1. The untreated (control) wood fiber was the most thermally stable while holocellulose ranked lowest among the three fiber types considered in this study. The weight loss due to thermal degradation of the untreated and acetone extracted fibers occurred in two distinctive steps. The first and second degradation peaks were 330°C and 369°C, respectively, for untreated pine and 323°C and 367°C, respectively, for acetone extracted fiber (Figure 1). Kim et al.24 stated that the degradation of hemicelluloses, lignin, and cellulose occurred between 180°C and 350°C, 250°C and 500°C, and 275°C and 350°C, respectively. Therefore, the two peaks observed can be attributed to the lignin and cellulose degradation, respectively. Although, holocellulose fiber was marked with two conspicuous degradation steps at 266°C and 346°C (Figure 1), the polymers responsible for these degradation steps are respectively, hemicelluloses and cellulose. The lowest degradation peak at 266°C did not occur in the untreated and acetone extracted fibers; this suggests that the degradation of hemicellulose and lignin in these two fiber types had poor resolution (end and onset points of hemicellulose and lignin, respectively, are not distinctively separated) whereby only that of the lignin was conspicuous. The lower degradation temperature of cellulose in the holocellulose fiber was contrary to what was expected (higher thermal stability). A possible explanation is that cellulose Mw is reduced during chlorite delignification25 thus lowering the degradation temperature. TGA tests showed that wood polymers degradation would not have occurred during WPC production because the set temperatures in both the barrel and die of the extruder are below the wood polymers decomposition temperatures. TGA: thermogravimetric analysis.

sec.title: Mechanical and water sorption properties
sec.p:
The densities of WPC (1330–1370 kg/m3) made from the control, acetone extracted, and holocellulose fibers are significantly different (Table 1). Holocellulose-based PVC composites ranked the lowest density while untreated (control) the heaviest among the three WPC types. Generally, extractives and lignin contributes to the density of wood; so it is expected that control pine fiber-based WPC was the heaviest. Flexural properties of modified wood-based PVC composites are presented in Table 1. The results showed that there were no significant differences in the flexural strength (MOR) among the composites made from control pine fibers, acetone extracted pine fibers, and holocellulose fibers. However, the MOE of holocellulose-based WPC was significantly higher than WPC from the other fiber sources and possibly due to the high cellulose content.26 Table 1.

Among the composites produced from the control and treated pine fiber, PVC/holocellulose ranked poorly in the WA tests after 24 h through 1176 h water soak (Figure 2). This is expected since holocellulose is more hydrophilic and porous than wood fiber containing extractives and lignin. Unexpectedly, the TS of the PVC/holocellulose was less than that of PVC/pine. Acetone extracted wood fiber-based WPC performed extremely well (WA and TS) above the untreated wood fiber-based WPC. The removal of the extractive content might have contributed to the improved interaction between the exposed wood polymers and PVC. However, delignification reduced the plasticity interaction of the delignified wood and PVC; thereby caused increase in the TS of holocellulose over the acetone extracted fiber-based WPC. Generally, the presence of the combination of extractives and lignin contribute to the lack of compatibility (poor interfacial bonding/interaction) between wood and PVC resulting in high TS of PVC/pine composite. sec.title: Surface appearance
sec.p:
SEMs of unweathered, 400 and 1200 h xenon-arc weathered PVC-based WPC are shown in Figure 3. Small size cracks were observed on the surface of all the weathered PVC-based composites; the extent of cracks is wood fiber type (control, acetone extracted fiber and holocellulose) dependent. It was observed that PVC seemed to have poor interfacial bonding with the holocellulose fiber in the unweathered WPC. Nevertheless, relative to the unweathered WPC, holocellulose-filled PVC ranked the best because it was not severely degraded compared to its corresponding untreated pine and acetone extracted fiber-based WPC. Figure 3.

SEM: scanning electron micrograph; PVC: polyvinyl chloride.

Figure 4 shows the relative lightness (ΔLrel) and total color change (ΔEab) of xenon-arc and outside weathered modified wood-based PVC composites. PVC/holocellulose WPC had the lowest ΔLrel while the PVC/acetone extracted fiber WPC had the highest ΔLrel. The ΔLrel of the PVC-based WPC produced from control fiber was significantly different from that of acetone extracted pine fiber (α = 0.05) when subjected to both xenon arc and outside weathering. The higher ΔLrel value of the acetone extracted fiber-based WPC than the untreated control pine WPC could be due to the lignin degradation (removal of extractive exposed more lignin to weathering factors). This is contrary to the observation made for HDPE/modified wood; the ΔLrel of untreated and extractive free pine fiber was not significantly different.14 This implies that plastic type also plays a significant role during WPC weathering with respect to wood modification. The fact that PVC/holocellulose WPC was more color stable in term of lightness of the weathered surface implies that application where color stability is a requirement (in a moderately dry environment) favors the use of holocellulose (delignified) fiber. The relative lightness and total color change of all the PVC/modified WPC increased upon weathering until 800 h and 90 days for xenon-arc and outside weathering regimes, respectively (Figure 4). Additionally, wood modification and exposure time significantly affect the ΔLrel and ΔEab (α = 0.05) of xenon arc and outside weathered PVC composites. Figure 4.

sec.title: Infrared spectroscopy
sec.p:
Infrared spectra of unweathered and xenon-arc weathered untreated pine and holocellulose-based PVC composites are shown in Figure 5. These spectra show that there are some important spectral modifications that occurred in the weathered PVC-based composites due to the formation of new or increased functional groups. For PVC/pine composites, the spectral structures at different regions were defined and assigned by Fabiyi and McDonald;4 C–O group (1015–1050 cm−1) and OH (3080–3500 cm−1) which identify the present of cellulose, hemicellulose, and lignin in wood.27,28 The band at 1508–1512 cm−1 was assigned to lignin. For control pine and acetone extracted pine-based PVC composites, there was a decrease in the lignin assigned peak due to longer weathering time (Figure 5). However, this band (1508–1512 cm−1) was not present, as expected, in the PVC/holocellulose composites. More importantly, the bands between 1680 and 1800 cm−1 present in the composites were assigned to the carbonyl functional groups.29 The carbonyl present include: γ-peracids at 1778 cm−1 (or acid chloride); ester (or α–α′-dichloroketones) groups at (1745–1728 cm−1);30 and β-chlorocarboxylic acids (1725–1715 cm−1).31 It was evident that oxidation occurred on the weathered surface due to an increase in band intensity and band broadening of the carbonyl groups (Figure 5). Figure 5.
FT-IR spectra of (top) unweathered and 1200 h xenon-arc weathered PVC/pine composites and (bottom) carbonyl region (1800–1680 cm−1) of xenon-arc weathered PVC/holocellulose composites (0, 400, 1200 h).
FT-IR: Fourier transform infrared; PVC: polyvinyl chloride.

The concentrations of carbonyl groups (1680–1800 cm−1) were determined using an equation derived by Fabiyi et al.19 from Beer–Lambert equation. Wood degradation (from hydroxyl group at 3080–3500 cm−1) in weathered PVC-based WPC was quantified as hydroxyl index. The concentration of the carbonyl (γ-peracids or acid chloride at 1778 cm−1; ester or α–α′-dichloroketones at 1745–1728 cm−1; and β-chlorocarboxylic acids at 1725–1715 cm−1) increased upon WPC weathering for both control and modified wood (Figures 6 and 7). In all the identified carbonyl groups, PVC/holocellulose composites had the lowest carbonyl concentration compared to the untreated control and acetone extracted fiber-based PVC composites. Chemical changes due to weathering are more affected in control and acetone extracted fiber-based PVC composites as evidenced in the oxidation estimation. However, the three composites types (untreated control, acetone extracted, and holocellulose fibers-based PVC composites) show vulnerability to further degradation because these carbonyl groups are photolabile. The concentration of the C = C groups at 1635 cm−1 present in weathered PVC/modified wood composites increased upon weathering (Figure 6). It is clear that PVC/holocellulose composite had the lowest C = C concentration in both outside and xenon-arc weathering regimes thereby resulting in the formation of less unsaturated functionality. In addition, the hydroxyl and lignin indices decreased upon extended exposure time in xenon-arc weatherometer (Figure 8). This is an indication that wood was lost upon extended exposure time. sec.title: MW distribution of the weathered polymer
sec.p:
Generally, Mw and Mn of PVC matrix decreased upon longer exposure of PVC-based WPC produced from untreated, acetone extracted, and holocellulose fibers to xenon-arc and outside weathering (Tables 2 and 3). The reduction in both Mw and Mn of PVC indicates that chain scission was the predominate reaction. Polydispersity (Mw/Mn) of all the xenon and outside weathered wood fibers-based PVC composites did not show any clear trend (Table 4). The inconsistent increase/decrease in the polydispersity of the PVC makes it difficult to comment of the possibility of cross-linking reaction occurrence due to prolonged exposure to outside and xenon-arc weathering regimes. It has been noted that chain scission reactions have a direct influence on Mn, and that the number of apparent chain scissions per molecule, Nscission, can be obtained from the following relationship (equation (28)):10 (28)Nscission=Mn,0Mn,t-1 where Mn,0 and Mn,t are the number-average MWs of the unweathered and at exposure time, respectively. However, Hoekstra et al.32 gave another version of chain scission reactions, which was expressed in terms of the number of scission events per gram of material as given in equation (29) (29)Nt=1Mn,t-1Mn,0

From the results shown in Figure 9, number of chain scissions (both in scission per molecule and mol/g) increased with longer exposure time of the PVC/modified wood composites in xenon-arc weathering except for PVC/holocellulose composites. MacCallum33 reported that the relationship between number of scissions and time would be linear if degradation processes occur with random scissions. Therefore, the results obtained in this study suggest that stepwise degradation reaction occur during PVC composites weathering. There is no significant change in the number of chain scissions reactions after 400 h of xenon-arc weathering of PVC/control pine and PVC/holocellulose composites. This observation could be due to the presence of stabilizers in PVC. sec.title: Relationship between outside and xenon-arc weathering
Mechanism of color and chemical changes
sec.p:
Based on equation (27), the second-order polynomial equations presented in Tables 5 to 7 were obtained from laboratory data used for plotting Figures 4, 6, and 7. It was observed that both the theoretical and laboratory data for the color changes (ΔLrel and ΔEab) and chemical changes (vinyl and carbonyl concentrations) of xenon-arc and outside weathered WPC were in agreement using second-order polynomial equation. The results suggest that second-order reaction kinetics best described the degradation (color fade and chemical change) of PVC-based wood composites. Since the curves are second-order polynomial, it then suggests that the reactions that took place during xenon arc and outside weathering of PVC/modified wood WPC, irrespective of fiber type (untreated, acetone extracted, and holocellulose fibers), followed a stepwise degradation and similar mechanism. This means that other properties and formulations could be successfully modeled and used to screen new WPC formulations for photodegradation. Table 5.

sec.title: Prediction of outside weathered WPC properties from xenon-arc weathering
sec.p: It must be noted that accelerated tests are not 100% reliable in predicting what happens at the outside weathering regime. In the accelerated weathering regime mainly the artificial light, temperature and water spray are factors being considered and strictly controlled. However, uncontrolled sunlight, temperature, rain, dew, humidity, biological, acid deposits, dirt, and contaminants as well as other physical objects occur in the outside weathering. In addition, the number of cycle per 24 h is determined and each cycle is timed in accelerated weathering while the cycle number and time are not pre-determined in the outside. Therefore, from this preliminary study predicting outside weathering from accelerated weathering requires the data from outdoor weathering as a baseline.

The models developed from the relationships between outside and xenon-arc weathering at a given exposure time (h) are presented in Table 8. A typical illustration of the predicted color fade (lightness) and carbonyl concentration of outside weathered PVC-based WPC is shown in Figure 10. Therefore, laboratory accelerated weathering data (color and chemical) can be relied on to predict PVC WPC behavior, of differing fiber types, if models are based on second polynomial degradation. More importantly, these relationships (developed models) have been extrapolated up to 4000 h and still found useful for outside weathering prediction (Figure 10). The models developed in this study are only valid for weathering exposure for PVC-based WPC of differing wood fiber types. Note that good correlation means that the shape of the curves of the plot of color or chemical change versus time obtained in both weathering regimes (accelerated and outside) follow the same pattern and mechanism, irrespective of fiber type.34 The practical implication of a study like this is based on the establishment of the fact that xenon arc accelerated weathering can be used to predict the outside weathering and used to screen WPC formulations for service life. Future study would focus on the use of the derived model (equation (27)) to predict the moisture sorption and mechanical properties of different WPC formulations. Figure 10.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this study, the effects of modifying wood fibers on the water sorption and mechanical properties of unweathered as well as color and chemical changes of weathered PVC/modified wood composites were examined. It was observed that holocellulose-based WPC exhibited poor water sorption than acetone extracted and untreated wood fiber-based WPC. However, holocellulose-based WPC was significantly stiff compared to the untreated and acetone extracted fiber-based WPC. The change in color and surface oxidation increased upon longer exposure of all the PVC-based composites. During weathering, the PVC’s MW decreased upon longer exposure time. In this study, chain scission predominates over cross-linking, as indicated by both the decrease in average MW and the associated accrual of oxidation products whose formation is preferential by chain scissions. Kinetic modeling of the changes in color, vinyl (unsaturation), and carbonyl concentrations showed that a stepwise degradation (second-order polynomial degradation) mechanism was followed by xenon-arc and outside weathered PVC/modified wood WPC. From these results, holocellulose (delignified wood) based composites had the lowest color fade (lightness), less morphological change, and less MW change on the surface of weathered composites. Therefore, holocellulose may be preferred as a fiber type for WPC production for applications where color stability is of high priority. Additionally, special attention must be given to making the holocellulose fiber dimensionally stable. From the developed models, the effects of outside weathering on color and carbonyl concentration of PVC-based WPC can be predicted from xenon-arc weathering and exposure time.
